before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"ai9l1","text":"Keep your original stock safe and aliquoted. For large plasmids with complementary sequences such as LTR sites, keep in mind that repeated reamplification from an already reamplified stock may lead to an accumulation of recombined plasmids and a poorer distribution of library elements.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"8p7sq","text":"In this protocol, we describe a stepwise procedure for the re-amplification of sgRNA libraries in liquid culture. In our hands, this protocol works reliably to amplify pre-cloned sgRNA libraries (e.g. order from Addgene) in a way that preserves the distribution of library elements.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5ei8d","text":"After electroporation, add the    resuspended cells in a 14 ml culture tube and incubate the cells in a thermoshaker    .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":31,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":118,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7o342","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ake8t","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5se1v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6p415","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65h35","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"1","error":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}},"1":{"type":"shaker","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":3600,"error_shaker":false,"error_temperature":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"scientificNotation":{"shaker":false,"temperature":false},"shaker":"600","start":null,"temperature":"37","temperatureUnit":10,"unit":33}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7uhn6","text":"In general, an incubation temperature of 37°C is optimal for cell recovery. Since E. coli tend to recombine plasmids with complementary sequences (e.g. LTRs), recovery temperature can be reduced to 30°C. This may however, result in a lower total number of recovered cells.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"67o4a","text":"Use a small fraction of your cells to determine the electroporation efficiency of the reamplification. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9lnem","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f2qq1","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6smn2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"620p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cji7l","text":"In this step, much depends on the size of the particular plasmid and the number of elements in the library. Therefore, the dilution factor must be chosen based on properties of the library and the scale of the electroporation. Smaller plasmids yield significantly more colonies than large ones, and an upscaled plasmid input at the electroporation step may result in higher dilutions being required to achieve a countable number on the respective agar plates after plating.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8grvc","text":"On the next day, check for overall coverage via colony counting on  . The overall colony count should be 1000x the element number of your library.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":67,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9ug4d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"br534","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"afs8o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"reagents","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":false,"cas_number":"","guid":"412EE6DB341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","linfor":"","mol_weight":0,"name":"LB agar plates with the proper antibiotic (e.g. Kanamycin)","pubchem_id":"0","public":1,"rrid":"","sku":"","stats":{"total_protocols":0},"url":"","vendor":{"id":0,"image":{"placeholder":null,"source":"/img/vendors/1.png"},"is_requested":false,"link":"https://www.protocols.io","name":"Contributed by users"}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bojh","text":"Below we provide a simplified example for how to determine transformation coverage. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":33,"offset":1,"style":"bold"},{"length":33,"offset":1,"style":"UNDERLINE"},{"length":6,"offset":320,"style":"UNDERLINE"}],"key":"fsvbc","text":"\nExample calculation of coverage:  On the 1:10,000 dilution plate we count 100 colonies. This gives us 100*10,000 = 1,000,000 total colonies. This total colony number is divided by the number of elements (e.g. sgRNAs) in the respective library. For a library the size of 1,000 sgRNAs, the coverage would 1,000,000/1,000=1,000x. For larger libraries, e.g. the size of the genome-wide Brunello library (80,000 sgRNAs), we would count the 1:1,000,000 dilution plate. In this case, 80 counted colonies would mean 80,000,000 total colonies which divided by the library size (80,000 sgRNAs) would again return a transformation coverage of 1,000x.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":34,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"clgu8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a84n","text":"Below we show an example chromatogram of an expected sequencing result. We recommend using sequencing primers 50-100 nt upstream of the sgRNA region. You should see clean traces up- and downstream of the SPACER region, and a noisy 20 nt signal in the SPACER region, due to the sgRNA diversity in your library. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ph3f","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ba09","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9n093","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"44kg0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"30fic","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"sample","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"blocks":null,"entityMap":null}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"height":144,"id":416265,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"46vii\",\"text\":\"Example of a Sanger sequencing result. \",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/jpeg","original_name":"Protocols.io.jpg","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/nysmb8bwf.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/nysjb8bwf.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/nyskb8bwf.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/nysib8bwf.webp","width":550}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1n7qq","text":"! To validate the distribution of elements in your library, we strongly recommend performing next generation sequencing of your plasmid pool before proceeding with downstream experiments. To do so, follow the NGS protocol provided with your library, using the plasmid pool as template, instead of the genomic DNA (as you would in CRISPR screens).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
